revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=May 2014}} '''''Smok Kaszubski''''' ("[[Kashubia]]n Dragon") was an improvised Polish [[armoured train]], which served in the Polish defenses during the [[Invasion of Poland|German invasion]] in 1939. The train was part of the [[Land Coastal Defence]]. The train was built in September 1939, at the initiative of ''[[Lieutenant (navy)|Kapitan marynarki]]'' Jerzy Błeszyński, by employees of the workshop of the naval port in [[Gdynia]]. For the construction of the steel plates, steel from the hulls of unfinished destroyers [[Grom class destroyer (1939)|''Orkan'' and ''Huragan'']] was used. The first commander of the train was ''Kapitan'' Błeszyński. After his injury on 9 September 1939 in [[Wejherowo]], command of the train was taken over by [[Lieutenant (junior grade)|''Porucznik marynarki'']] Florian Hubicki. The operating personnel of the train was mostly formed by the Gdynian railways workers and sailors from the former company servicing the port. Composition of the train:
- 1 × tank locomotive [[PKP class OKl27|OKl27]] armoured with steel plates
- 2 × armoured wagons for troops
- 2 × battle wagons Armament:
- 1 × Vickers 40mm AA gun, taken from [[ORP Mazur|ORP ''Mazur'']]
- 1 × 47 mm gun for saluting, taken from ORP ''Bałtyk''
- 11 × machine guns
- 30 × pistols from [[ORP Wicher (1928)|ORP ''Wicher'']] == See also == *[[List of armoured trains]] {{Polish Armoured Trains}} {{italictitle}} [[Category:Armoured trains of Poland]]
